places.generalDescription: Sentosa Island, located off the southern coast of Singapore, is a popular tourist destination known for its beautiful beaches, theme parks, and adventure activities. The island offers a wide range of attractions including Fort Siloso, Fort Siloso Skywalk, Butterfly Park & Insect Kingdom. Visitors can also enjoy upscale hotels and resorts with various dining options serving local and international cuisine. Sentosa Cove is a residential area on the island featuring luxurious mansions and condominium complexes with stunning sea views.

sources.snippet: One of Singapore‚Äôs greatest tourism projects, Sentosa has an array of beaches that cater to all different sorts of sun-seekers. Families can make a beeline for Palawan Beach, which has a suspension bridge linked to an offshore islet that the kids can clamber across. If you want to spend the day partying it up in style at a beach club, then head to Tanjong Beach, home to the ever-buzzing Tanjong Beach Club.

places.generalDescription: Sembawang Park is a serene coastal retreat located at the northernmost tip of Singapore, offering a peaceful beach facing the picturesque Strait of Johor. This 15-hectare park features tree-shaded areas with picnic shelters and grills, making it perfect for outdoor gatherings. Visitors can enjoy various activities such as beach volleyball, water sports like snorkeling and diving, or simply taking leisurely strolls along the shore.

sources.snippet: Five of the seven popular recreational beaches monitored by NEA are assessed to be suitable for primary contact activities as they are graded ‚ÄúGood‚Äù. These five beaches continue to meet the WHO water quality guidelines for recreational use. Sembawang Park and Pasir Ris beaches are graded ‚ÄúFair" dropping from "Good" in the previous year. Members of the public are advised to not swim and to not engage in other primary contact water activities at these two beaches. Signages on the beach advisory will be placed along Sembawang Park Beach and Pasir Ris Beach and will remain until further notice, when the water quality at these two beaches improves.

Changi Beach Park is one of the oldest coastal parks and is popular with locals for
its tranquillity and relaxed ambience. Approximately 3.3km long, this linear park has
stretches of pristine white beaches dotted with coconut palms and barbecue pits. The
park is in the vicinity of Changi Village, a vibrant corner of the island where good food,
bargains and various facilities await.
The kampong ambience has been carefully retained while a jogging track and other
amenities were added. Visitors can jog or cycle along the winding tracks to Changi
Ferry Terminal.
Also found within the district are places of interest, which are part of Singapore's natural
and historical heritage. Aside from the Changi Museum and Chapel, you can find
designated heritage trees, Pulau Ubin and Chek Jawa (a bumboat ride away). Changi
Beach Park promises to offer visitors a fun-filled recreational experience.

places.generalDescription: Coney Island, located at the far end of Punggol in Singapore, offers a rustic and diverse natural experience. The park is home to over 80 bird species and features lush coastal forests, mangroves, and beachside areas. Visitors can enjoy trekking through the ecologically sustainable park while observing wildlife such as eagles, brightly-colored birds, butterflies, otters, and macaques.

sources.snippet: In the north of Singapore within waving distance of Malaysia, you‚Äôll find Punggol Beach. This important historical site, where the Sook Ching Massacre of 1942 took place, is today a relatively deserted beach, made all the more mesmerizing by the black boulders strewn across the sand. We recommend combining a visit to Punggol with a trip to Coney Island: hire a bike near Punggol Jetty to cycle 15 minutes to the 100-hectare (247-acre) national park, where bike trails and secluded beaches abound.

ü™∂Coney Island also known as Palau Serangoon was once owned by Haw Par Brothers who built a villa on it, known as Haw Par Beach Villa.
ü™∂The island later went thorough several hands before the Singapore Government own it.
ü™∂It was then reclaimed to a larger area several times it's original size.
In the 1970s, Coney Island was an alternative picnic venue for many who wish to be away from the more crowded traditional site.
ü™∂It used to be accessible only by ferry from Punggol Jetty before land bridges were built.

places.generalDescription: Kusu Island, located in the Singapore Straits, is a small tropical paradise steeped in mystic legends. reviews.text:
As someone who grew up loving all things Disney, I've always been enchanted by the worlds they create the magical castles, the whimsical characters, and the unforgettable stories that have shaped my childhood. From the first time I watched Mickey Mouse light up the screen to the heartwarming adventures of Moana and Elsa, Disney has always felt like a place where dreams come to life.

So imagine this: one day, right here in Singapore, Coney Island transforms into a haven of Disney magic. On one side of the country, we already have Universal Studios, filled with action-packed adventures and thrilling rides. But on the other side, Coney Island becomes a whole new world, where fairy tales come alive and nature meets imagination.

In this magical vision, you'd step into a park that blends Disney's beloved characters with the beauty of Coney Island's natural landscape. Imagine walking along a serene nature trail where Pocahontas and Meeko greet you, or crossing a wooden bridge that leads straight into Moana's tropical island paradise. The gentle sounds of waves crashing blend perfectly with the cheerful music of Disney's classic tunes.

The centerpiece of the park could be an eco-friendly castle maybe inspired by Elsa's ice palace but built with solar panels and surrounded by lush greenery. From there, each land would branch out like pages of a storybook. Picture an outdoor amphitheater where Simba and Rafiki teach lessons about the circle of life, or an enchanted forest where Tinker Bell's pixie dust sparkles at dusk.

What makes this dream even more exciting is how perfectly it balances Singapore's love for modernity and nature. The park could have sustainable rides, quiet electric boats floating through magical lagoons, and even treehouse hotels inspired by Tarzan's jungle home. And when the sun sets, the night would come alive with dazzling fireworks, lighting up the skies over Coney Island and reflecting off the water.

Having Universal Studios on one side of Singapore and Disney magic on the other would make our little red dot the ultimate entertainment destination in Asia. Families could spend weekends going between thrilling Hollywood adventures and heartwarming Disney tales. Tourists from all over the world would flock to Singapore not just for the food and sights but to experience a perfect blend of action, nature, and magic.

For someone like me, who has always loved Disney, this would be a dream come true. A place where childhood memories meet the beauty of Singapore's landscapes, creating something uniquely magical. If one day this dream becomes reality, I'd be the first in line at the gates of Disney's Coney Island, ready to step into a world where imagination truly has no limits.

Great place to explore in Singapore! Green and beautiful.
I rent a bike at Bike Stop At Waterway and cycled in Coney Island. It was a pleasant ride, in 40 minutes you can ride around the island.

A great place to cycle and explore and surprised it was crowded in a hot Sunday afternon. Feel soothing and relaxing despite the heat. Think there is a development too with construction going within the island.

places.generalDescription: Pasir Ris Beach, which means "Narrow beach" in Malay, is a popular destination in Singapore for outdoor activities and natural beauty. The beach stretches for about 6 kilometers and is surrounded by parkland with various facilities such as BBQ pits, cycling tracks, and pony rides. Visitors can enjoy birdwatching from the parks' watching tower or hike through the lush mangrove forests. Additionally, there are dining options available nearby at places like Five Rabbits Bistro and Georges.

sources.snippet: Five of the seven popular recreational beaches monitored by NEA are assessed to be suitable for primary contact activities as they are graded ‚ÄúGood‚Äù. These five beaches continue to meet the WHO water quality guidelines for recreational use. Sembawang Park and Pasir Ris beaches are graded ‚ÄúFair" dropping from "Good" in the previous year. Members of the public are advised to not swim and to not engage in other primary contact water activities at these two beaches. Signages on the beach advisory will be placed along Sembawang Park Beach and Pasir Ris Beach and will remain until further notice, when the water quality at these two beaches improves.

If you're looking for a luxurious escape from Singapore's bustling city life, Unwind at Lazarus Island offers an exclusive and relaxing experience. Arriving by private yacht adds a touch of sophistication, setting the tone for a serene getaway.

The island itself is a hidden gem, with pristine beaches, crystal-clear waters, and a peaceful ambiance perfect for sunbathing, picnicking, or simply enjoying the ocean breeze. reviews.text: Great place to go for a low tidal walk and explore the rich treasures of aquatic life around the islands. You must bring along water, food and mats because you won't find any shop there but they do have toilets there. There are some bbq pits on the island.

Fun place to visit for a few hours to explore, picnic and swim. But watch out for monkeys attempting to steal your food!

Bring insect repellent too; plenty of mosquitos and sandflies.

-1 star because the toilet here leaves much to be desired.

I had a chance to visit Pulau Hantu via Lee Kong Chian National History Museum (LKCNHM) - Intertidal Walk. I have not tried to get there by myself, but for sure I will figure out the way soon, still, many places I have not discovered yet.

It was such a great experience for me. We gathered at MSP at 7 am in the morning. The staff is extremely friendly and they even gave each of us a milo packet. After a short introduction and briefing, do's and don'ts, we headed to the boat. From MSP to the island, it will take roughly 1 hour, so for those who have seasick, please get yourself some pills. There is no restroom on the boat as well, so get yourself ready before leaving, or you have to wait until the end of the intertidal walk, before heading back to the mainland.

We got there at around 8-ish and started walking slowly through the camping area to the shore. There, you can find the local marine biodiversity during low tides. The staff will help you identify the creature and tell you some facts about it. We encountered sea stars, sea cucumber, some different types of crabs (the crab in my picture is the Hairy Crab or Teddy Crab), limpets, sea cockroaches, coral (anemone - house of Nemo is also there), seaweed, seagrass, etc. If you can spot some weird creature, just let the staff know, who knows, just like me, I suddenly spotted a Ribbon Worm, a little bit creepy but good to learn about it.

For those who don't want to get dirty or don't like those cleaning up activities, I would not recommend this tour since at the end of the intertidal walk, there will be a coastal clean-up activity. At around 10:30 am, our group started to pick up the trash and we successfully collected 5kg of trash, not much, but we are contributing something for the environment. The staff will also provide some statistics about trash that have been collecting for years. It could be a great data source for those students who are doing projects related to the environment. At 11 am we headed back to the mainland.

(+) of the intertidal walk tour:
- Marine life knowledge
- Clear instruction before starting the tour (What to expect, what to bring and wear, what to do during the walk, etc.)
- Friendly staff, willing to answer any questions of your
- Punctuality
- You can take plenty picturesque photos as well.
- Good choice for kids who want to explore more about the biodiversity of the low tides.
- Related information of the intertidal walk can be searched online easily

(-) of the intertidal walk tour:
- We purchased the ticket via Sistic - which is $107.00/ per pax. We understand the museum needs to use the money for many purposes (salary, boat tickets, operation cost, and so on) but we wish we could have a longer walk with more discoveries.
- Quite sunny so be prepared to get tanned.

P/S: I will definitely comeback here again to explore the other areas of the island.

Changi Beach is a peaceful and scenic coastal park, perfect for a quiet escape from the city. One of Singapore's oldest beach parks, it has a nostalgic charm and a laid-back atmosphere. The stretch toward Changi Village is especially serene and less crowded, even on weekends - great for sunrise views, beach walks, or simply enjoying the sea breeze and a quiet moment by the water.

You won't find the soft sands and clear waters of tropical resort beaches here - no one really swims - but it's a lovely place to soak in the sunset, watch planes from nearby Changi Airport, or picnic with family. Facilities like BBQ pits and fitness stations add convenience, and being close to Changi Village means you're just a short walk away from local eats like the famous nasi lemak.

Beyond its natural beauty, Changi Beach also holds historical significance. During World War II, it was one of the sites of the Sook Ching massacre, where many Chinese civilians tragically lost their lives. A commemorative plaque near Camp Site 2 honors the victims and serves as a quiet, powerful reminder of the area's complex past. I'd rate it a solid 4 out of 5 - simple, meaningful, and a peaceful slice of Singapore.

places.generalDescription: Sentosa Island, located off the southern coast of Singapore, boasts three beautiful sandy beaches: Tanjong Beach, Palawan Beach, and Siloso Beach. There are three distinct beaches on Sentosa Island for you to laze about on that cater for different types of beach goers ‚Äì Siloso Beach, Palawan Beach and Tanjong Beach. You can also purchase multiple discounted tickets online for all things Sentosa (beyond the beach) such as the Sentosa Fun Pass, Cable Car Sky Pass, S.E.A. reviews.text:
Very nice beach in Singapore. Not to overcrowded and with just enough options for food and drink. Wood fired pizza was a big hit!
Be sure to take a ride on the sky train. We'll worth the 15 dollars.
Note; if you take a taxi in, you will need to take the bus back up to "Beach Station" to get a taxi back out and off the island.

Getting to Siloso Beach is a breeze ‚Äì just hop on the Sentosa Express for only $4 (as of April 2025). The beach offers a perfect spot to relax, unwind, and enjoy a peaceful picnic. While there's not much in terms of activities, the laid-back atmosphere makes it a great place to chill. If you're planning to visit the bar, just order a beer to snag a seat and take in the stunning sunset views. For a quieter experience, try coming in the afternoon when it's less crowded, though it can get busier as the evening rolls in, especially around peak time.

Walk through a wide, wooden bridge to reach the man made Siloso Beach Island. There are rock outcroppings for you to sit on and enjoy the breeze as you rest on your laurels. Enjoy the magnificent view of the multitude of ships by the sea and horizon as you breathe in the smell of diesel.

places.generalDescription: Tanjong Rimau is a hidden treasure tucked away on the western side of Sentosa, Singapore. The best time to explore this enchanting spot is during low tide when you can stroll along the rocky shore and discover fascinating creatures like starfish and crabs.

One of the things I appreciated the most about this spot is how secluded it feels - it's hard to find such serenity in Singapore with no crowds or noise pollution around. Overall, it's a beautiful and unique spot in Singapore to explore the coastline and enjoy the peaceful scenery

Saint John's Island was an unforgettable adventure, even with the rain! The drizzle added a fresh, misty vibe to the island, making it feel even more like a hidden paradise. We went for a swim in the clear, warm waters, and the experience was so refreshing. The real highlight, though, was encountering the local monkeys up close ‚Äì they were curious and playful, which made the experience even more memorable.
